text:
1. What led you to the particular district in which you settled?

   MET A FRIEND IN YORKTON.

   THROUGH WHAT INFORMATION ABOUT IT OBTAINED?

   ASKED RESIDENTS.

   WHAT WAS THE EXTENT OF THIS INFORMATION AND WHAT ALTERNATIVES DID YOU CONSIDER?

   HE SAID IT WAS GOOD LAND - NO.

2. What was your previous experience in farming?

   FORMED OUT FOR A FEW YEARS.

   IF NONE, UNDER WHAT CIRCUMSTANCES DID YOU TOWNSHIP?

3. Did you homestead?

   YES.

   IF SO, GIVE DESCRIPTION OF THE LAND (TOWNSHIP, RANGE, DISTANCE FROM THE RAILWAY).

   10-32-11 WEST OF THE SECOND MILESTONE.

   WHEN, WHERE, AND HOW DID YOU FILE YOUR HOMESTEAD ENTRY?

   J. Y. YEBETO ON THE 10 AUGUST 1906.

   HOW MUCH INFORMATION DID YOU HAVE ABOUT THE LAND WHEN YOU FILLED YOUR ENTRY?

   VERY LITTLE.

4. Did you obtain a pre-emption?

   NO.

5. What other land did you purchase?

   SW. 11-32-11 WEST OF THE 2ND MILESTONE.

6. Have any of it Hudson Bay Company land, C. P. R. land, or school land?

   SONG L. LAND.

What was the purchase price per acre?

$10 AN ACRE.

What was the largest amount you possessed at one time? (Give date)

NO MORE THAN TWO QUARTERS.
1. What led you to the particular district in which you settled?

2. What was your previous experience in farming?

3. Did you homestead?

4. Did you obtain a pre-emption?

5. What other land did you purchase?

6. What was the purchase price per acre?
7. Did you retain the original homestead?
   If you moved, tell where and for what reasons.

8. You may not wish to answer questions about how you financed your farming operation. However, if you care to, answers to the following would be of general interest. However, if you care to, answers to the following would be of

How did you finance your original purchase of land?

How long was it before you had completely paid for your land?

Did you ever finish paying for it?

Did you at any time mortgage your property or obtain loans?

YES

What interest rates did you pay?

9. What were your first buildings? (Give dates).

   * PR COTT
   * HOUSE AND BARN IN 1906

What material was used and where was it obtained?

What type of fencing did you engage in, originally and latest? (Give)

Livestock, mixed, etc.

10. How many acres did you break the first year?

The second?

The third?

Did you have cows, horses, or steam power for breaking?

Did horses and oxen?

12. What breaking crop did you grow?

Wheat

What other crops did you grow?

13. What kind and breed of livestock did you raise? (Give dates at which you started each. If discontinued, show.)

Horses and cattle of mixed breeds
7. Did you retain the original homestead?
   If you moved, sold, share out or lost land?

8. You may not wish to answer questions about how you financed your purchase of land.

9. How long was it before you had completely paid for your land?

10. Did you at any time mortgage your property or obtain loans?

11. What interest rates did you pay?

12. What were your first buildings? (Give dates)

13. House and barn in 1906

14. What materials were used and where were they obtained?

15. Lots obtained on the farm

16. What type of fencing did you engage in, originally and latest (fencing, livestock, trees, etc.)

17. Livestock

18. How many acres did you break the first year?

19. The second?

20. The third?

21. Did you use oxen, horses, or steam power for breaking?

22. What breaking crop did you grow?

23. What other crops did you grow?

24. What kinds and breeds of livestock did you raise? (Give dates of which you started each)

25. Horses and cattle of mixed breeders
14. If you used oxen, how many did you have?
   When and where did you obtain them?

THREE OXEN BORROWED IN 1910

Did you have any memorable experiences with them?
NONE

15. When did you first use horses for motive power?
   Where did you obtain them?

IN 1910 AT ARGAPIA CASE.

What was the largest number of horses you kept?

26

16. With what machinery did you start farming?
   PLOW AND HARROW AND A DRILL

17. What was the first tractor you used, and when?
   Was it used for field power or for field power?

YES IT WAS FOR FIELD POWER

If this was not the first tractor in your district, do you remember the first? Give details.

DO NOT KNOW AS WE JUST MOVED INTO THE FISHING LAKE DISTRICT IN 1917

18. To what extent did other members of the family assist in farming operations?
   FIVE CHILDREN AND ALL HELPED AS LONG AS THEY WERE HOME

Must was the first hired help you had?

MY BROTHER IN LAW

What wages were paid?

$25

To what extent did you make use of hired help during your farming career?

ALWAYS HAD HIRED HELP UNTIL THE CHILDREN BECAME OLD ENOUGH TO HELP

19. Do you recall examples of informal cooperative efforts in your district,
   such as neighbors working together, etc.?
14. If you used oxen, how many did you have?
Then and where did you obtain them?

Taken back homeward in 1910.

Did you have any memorable experiences with them?

NONE

15. When did you first use horses for motive power?
Where did you obtain them?

1910 at Argodia saw.

What was the largest number of horses you kept?

26

16. With what machinery did you start farming?

PIERON AND HERRON AND A DRILL

17. What was the first tractor you used and when?

1930 Fordson for both power or for field power?

FIELD

If this was not the first tractor in your district, do you remember the first? Give details.

Do not know as we just moved into the Fishing Lake District in 1917.

18. To what extent did oldest members of the family assist in farming operations?

FIVE CHILDREN AND ALL HELPED AS LONG AS THEY WERE HOME

Most was the first hired help you had?

MY BROTHER IN 1910

Most wages were paid.

25¢

To what extent did you take use of hired help during your farming career?

ALWAYS HAD HIRE HELP UNTIL THE CHILDREN WERE OLD ENOUGH TO HELP.

19. Do you recall examples of informal cooperative efforts in your district, such as neighbors writing together?

BARN RAISINGS
20. Did you follow the practice of summer fallowing to begin with?
   If not, when did you begin?
   STARTED IN 1915

21. What rotation of crops did you practice?
   ALTERNATE WHEAT, OATS AND BARLEY

22. Where did you obtain your original seed?
   FROM A NEIGHBOR
   WHAT WAS THE VARIETY?
   MARQUIS BANNER
   THE PRICE WAS 65 CENTS FOR 25 SEEDS

23. What was the earliest date of planting you recall?
   APRIL 1912
   The latest date of harvesting you recall?
   AUGUST 10, 1914
   SEPTEMBER 1, 1919

24. What hazards or difficulties did you experience? You might give details such as drought, severity, damage, methods of control, wind, hail, frost, blizzards, floods, drought, prairie fires, rust, smut, grasshoppers, cutworms, sawflies, caterpillars, moles, mice, hawks, gophers, coyotes.

BAD WEATHER STORMS HAIL OUT LOTS OF FROST
20. Did you follow the practice of summer fallowing to begin with?
   If not, when did you begin?
   STARTED IN 1915

21. What rotation of crops did you practice?
   ALTERNATE WHEAT, OATS AND BARLEY

22. Where did you obtain your original seed?
   FROM A NEIGHBOR
   MAT OF THE VARIETY

23. What was the earliest date of harvesting you recall?
   (Give year)
   The Latest April in 1912
   The Latest in 1914

24. What hazards or difficulties did you experience? You might give details
   such as disease, severity, damage, methods of control, with respect to the
   following: hail, frost, wind and dust, blizzard, floods, drought, prairie
   fires, rust, smut, grasshoppers, cutworms, snails, caterpillars,
   magpies, hawks, gophers, coyotes.

BAD WIND STORMS HAIL OUT LOTS OF FROST
25. What weeds were present in your district when you first arrived and which were most common?

SOW THISTLE AND CAN. THISTLE ONE AS BAD AS THE OTHER.

26. What new varieties of seeds appeared after you settled? (Give date of appearance if possible).

RUSSIAN THISTLE IN 1940

27. What method of harvesting and threshing grain did you first use?

PLATED HARROWS UNTIL 1912

28. How many acres were used in these operations?

10 acres

29. When did you first market grain, livestock, or other produce from your farm?

1903 GRAIN LIVESTOCK IN 1917

30. How did you haul grain to market?

By horse

31. Was your grain hauled in the fall, or did you do winter hauling with team and sleigh?

OF AND ON FALL AND WINTER

32. To what point from Lake

How far? 8 MILES

33. What prices did you receive?

WHEAT 35 CENTS - OATS 15 CENTS

34. Was the flat warehouse ever used for loading grain in your district?

DELIVERED TO WESTERN ELEVATOR

35. In what year was the first grain elevator constructed in your district?

By date company? 1902-1950
25. What weeds were present in your district when you first arrived and which were most common?

SOW THISTLE AND CAN. THISTLE ONE AS BAD AS THE OTHER

26. What new varieties of weeds appeared after you settled? (Give date of appearance if possible).

RUSSIAN THISTLE IN 1940

ALTERED HARVESTING AND THRESHING GRAIN DID YOU FIRST USE?

27. What method of harvesting and threshing grain did you first use?

ALTERED HARVESTING UNTIL 1912

STAYLET JOHNSON

28. When did you first market grain, livestock, or other produce from your farm?

1900 GRAIN LIVESTOCK IN 1917

How did you haul grain to market?

The cost of your grain handling in the fall, or did you do winter handling with team and sleigh?

OF AND ON FALL AND WINTER

To what point from Lake

How far? 8 MILES

What prices did you receive?

WHEAT 3¢ QUARTS - OATS 15 CENTS

29. Was the first warehouse ever used for loading grain in your district? (Give date)

DELIVERED TO NORTHERN ELEVATOR

In what year was the first grain elevator constructed in your district?

By whom constructed?

1909-1909
30. What variations do you recall in prices for your product? (the livestock)

From 3¢ cents in 1900 to $1.87 in 1953

31. Did you engage in ranching?

If so, give details as to kind and number of cattle in the early years of the ranch, number of men employed, breeders, etc.

Honorable W. W., Ky.

32. What was done by you or others in your district to improve crops and livestock by purchasing registered seed, purchased livestock, etc.? Not in the early days.

33. Did you participate in any exhibitions or fairs?

Individuals who brought their exhibits home won:

Cured ham and bacon won first prize for a colt

First for sheep made first for a team

Second for a team

34. What agricultural organizations did you join? Tell whom and for how long.

Co-op in 1920 in 1922

35. Did you raise poultry?

Yes, for household use or for market?

After he was married he shipped to hatcheries

Then did you first buy chicks from hatcheries?

1924

36. When did you commence gardening?

1922

What kinds of crops were grown?

All kinds
30. What variations do you recall in prices for your produce? the highest? the lowest?

From 36 cents in 1906 to $1.69 in 1953

31. Did you engage in ranching?

If so, give details as to kind and number of cattle in the early years of the ranch, number of men employed, brands, etc.

Horse Brand W., K.

32. What was done by you or others in your district to improve crops and livestock by procuring registered seed, purebred livestock, etc.?

Not in the early days

33. Did you participate in any exhibitions or fairs?

Indicate the nature of your exhibits and the prizes won.

Cured ham and bacon won first
First for brood mare
First for a colt
Second for a team

I might went for her e
That we were married in
1921 hence exhibit in
farm produce

34. What agricultural organizations did you join? Tell when and for how long.

Co-op in 1920, in 1922

35. Did you raise poultry?

Was this for household use or for market?

After we were married he shipped to hatcheries

When did you first buy chicks from hatcheries?

1924

36. When did you commence gardening?

1922

What garden crops were then grown?

All kinds
30. What variations do you recall in prices for your produce? The lowest?

From 36 cents in 1903 to $1.40 in 1952

31. Did you engage in ranching? If so, give details as to kind and number of cattle in the early years of the ranch, number of men employed, brands, etc.

Horse Brand W. K.

32. What was done by you or others in your district to improve crops and livestock by purchasing registered seed, purebred livestock, etc.? Not in the early days.

33. Did you participate in any exhibitions or fairs? Indicate if you won anything.

Indicates Fair Manager for your work in 1922. Farm Produce won.

Cured ham and bacon won first for a colt second for a team.

I might mention that we were married in 1921 hence exhibit in farm produce.

34. What agricultural organizations did you join? Co-op in 1920. In 1922.

35. Did you raise poultry? Yes, for household use or for market?

After we were married we shipped to hatcheries when did you first buy chicks from hatcheries?

1924.

36. When did you commence gardening? What types of crops were then grown?

All kinds.
30. What variations do you recall in prices for your produce? the highest?

FROM 36 CENTS IN 1908 TO $1.00 IN 1953

31. Did you engage in ranching?

If so, give details as to kind and number of cattle in the early years of
the ranch, number of men employed, brands, etc.

HORSE BRAND W. K.

32. What was done by you or others in your district to improve crops and livestock by procuring registered seed, purchased livestock, etc.?

NOT IN THE EARLY DAYS

33. Did you participate in any exhibitions or fairs?

INDIVIDUAL ACHIEVEMENTS FOR YOU:

CURED HAM AND BACON WORTH FIRST PLACE

FIRST ON SEED WARE FIRST FOR A COLT

THAT WE WERE MARRIED IN

1921 HOME EXHIBIT IN

FAIR PRODUCE

34. What agricultural organizations did you join? Tell when and for how long.

CO-OP IN 1920 IN 1922

35. Did you raise poultry?

YES, FOR HOUSEHOLD USE OR FOR MARKET?

AFTER WE WERE MARRIED WE SHIPPED TO HATCHERIES

WHEN DID YOU FIRST BUY CHICKS FROM HATCHERIES?

1924

36. When did you commence gardening?

WHICH VEGETABLE CROPS WERE THEN GROWN?

ALL KINDS
There were seeds obtained?

TOWN IN WINNIPEG

What were some of the varieties planted?

HOME STEAD PEAS MULTIPLIER ONIONS, HEAD LETTUCE, BARSHIP

MAX BEANS SQUASH CORN

37. Did you have native trees about your farmstead?

YES

When did you first plant (trees), if any?

CARAGANA HEDGE IN '1922

What kinds?

Are they still living, or did they die out after a period of time?

As far as I know

If so, any special cause?

38. When did you fence any significant part of your land? 1907

What was your reason for so doing?

TO CONTROL STOCK

What type of fencing was used?

WILLOW POSTS

39. Did you ever attempt to irrigate gardens or crops?

To what extent? (Give dates).

40. How was milk kept and cream saved?

HOUSE

When did you get a cream separator?

1922

What kind of churn did you use?

BARREL

What quantities of butter were made?

NOT TOO MUCH.

41. Were butter and eggs sold for cash or taken in trade by local merchants?

DEAL WITH MERCHANT EXCEPT AT MATCHERY SHIPPING TIME
There were seeds obtained?

Tried in Winnipeg

What were some of the varieties planted?

Homestead Peas Multiplier Onions, Head Lettuce, Parsnip

Was Beans Squash Corn

37. Did you have native trees about your farmstead?

Yes

When did you first plant poppy? Late fall

What kind(s)?

Are they still living, or did they die out after a period of time?

A. Far as I know

If so, any special cause?

38. When did you fence any significant part of your land? 1907

What was your reason for doing so?

To control stock

What type of fencing was used?

Willow Posts

39. Did you ever attempt to irrigate gardens or crops?

To what extent? (Give dates)

40. How was milk kept and cream saved?

Ice House

When did you get a cream separator?

What kind of churn did you use?

Barrel

What quantities of butter were made?

Not too much.

41. Were butter and eggs sold for cash or taken in trade by local merchants?

Dealt with merchant except at market day shipping time
Oxford
